conclusion: Understanding the problem of a pedestrian trying to catch up with a bus using a v-t graph.
The v-t graph shows velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis with two lines: one horizontal at 8 m/s and another starting at the origin increasing linearly.
The horizontal line at 8 m/s represents the pedestrian's constant speed.
The line starting at the origin and increasing linearly represents the bus's acceleration.
The pedestrian starts 36 meters away from the bus when the light turns green at t=0.
The slope of the bus's velocity-time graph gives its acceleration.
Calculating the bus's acceleration: a = (8 - 0) / 8 = 1 m/s².
Distance covered by the pedestrian at time t is s_pedestrian = 8 * t.
Position of the pedestrian relative to the starting point is position_pedestrian = 36 + 8*t.
Distance covered by the bus is s_bus = 0.5*t².
Setting position_pedestrian equal to position_bus to find when the pedestrian catches the bus: 36 + 8*t = 0.5*t².
Solving for t using the quadratic formula: t = [16 ± sqrt(544)] / 2.
Calculating t gives approximately 19.66 s (ignoring negative time).
Checking distances at t=19.66 s: position_pedestrian ≈ 193.28 m, s_bus ≈ 193.26 m.
The pedestrian catches up to the bus at approximately 19.66 seconds.
Checking if the pedestrian's velocity exceeds the bus's velocity: v_bus = t.
